Literature Review: The Toll signaling pathway, initially identified for its role in dorsoventral (DV) axis formation in Drosophila, has been a subject of extensive research due to its dual functionality in immunity and embryonic patterning across the animal kingdom. This literature review explores the neofunctionalization of Toll signaling in insects, focusing on its transition from an immune response mechanism to a pivotal role in DV patterning, with particular attention to studies in Tribolium, Nasonia, Oncopeltus, and Gryllus, as well as insights from non-insect hexapods. The integration of Toll signaling into an ancestral BMP-based patterning system at the base of the insects or during insect evolution represents a fascinating example of evolutionary innovation. This review synthesizes findings from recent studies to elucidate the mechanisms underlying this neofunctionalization and its implications for our understanding of germ layer evolution, mesoderm formation, and the development of the serosa and serosal cuticle. The role of Toll signaling in the extraembryonic serosa, an early differentiating tissue of most insect embryos, provides a plausible scenario for its co-option from an ancestral immune function to a new role in axis formation. This transition is supported by comparative studies across different insect species, which reveal a gradient in the reliance on Toll signaling for DV patterning, with a notable reduction and substitution by BMP signaling in insects more distantly related to Drosophila. The exploration of these mechanisms not only sheds light on the evolutionary dynamics of signaling pathways but also enhances our understanding of the developmental biology of insects and the evolutionary origins of complex body plans.
